title: Isaiah Chapter 59 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 59 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 59 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 59.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59:1, what is said about the LORD's hand and ear?
options: The LORD'S hand is shortened and his ear is heavy
The LORD'S hand is not shortened and his ear is not heavy
The LORD'S hand is shortened but his ear is not heavy
The LORD'S hand is not shortened but his ear is heavy
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD'S hand is not shortened and his ear is not heavy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:1 says, 'Behold, the LORD'S hand is not shortened, that it cannot save; neither his ear heavy, that it cannot hear.'

questions.question: What separates people from God according to Isaiah 59:2?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:2 states, 'But your iniquities have separated between you and your God, and your sins have hid his face from you.'

questions.question: In Isaiah 59:3, what are the hands said to be defiled with?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:3 says, 'For your hands are defiled with blood, and your fingers with iniquity.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59:4, what do people trust in?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:4 states, 'they trust in vanity, and speak lies.'

questions.question: What do the people hatch and weave as described in Isaiah 59:5?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:5 says, 'They hatch cockatrice' eggs, and weave the spider's web.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 59:6 states that their works become garments that cover them.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:6 states, 'Their webs shall not become garments, neither shall they cover themselves with their works.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59:7, what do their feet run to?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:7 says, 'Their feet run to evil, and they make haste to shed innocent blood.'

questions.question: What do the people not know according to Isaiah 59:8?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:8 states, 'The way of peace they know not.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 59:9 says that judgment is near and justice overtakes us.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:9 says, 'Therefore is judgment far from us, neither doth justice overtake us.'

questions.question: How do people grope according to Isaiah 59:10?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:10 states, 'We grope for the wall like the blind.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 59:11: 'We roar all like ______, and mourn sore like doves.'
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:11 says, 'We roar all like bears, and mourn sore like doves.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59:13, what do people speak against the LORD?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:13 states, 'speaking oppression and revolt, conceiving and uttering from the heart words of falsehood.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 59:14 says truth is fallen in the street and equity cannot enter.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:14 says, 'for truth is fallen in the street, and equity cannot enter.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59:17, what did the LORD put on as protection?
options: Righteousness as a breastplate and a helmet of salvation
A crown of gold and a robe of silk
A shield of faith and a sword of truth
A mantle of peace and sandals of readiness
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness as a breastplate and a helmet of salvation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:17 says, 'For he put on righteousness as a breastplate, and an helmet of salvation upon his head.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59:20, who shall come to Zion?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:20 says, 'And the Redeemer shall come to Zion.'

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 59 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 59 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer feels distant from God due to ongoing sin. According to Isaiah 59, what is the primary reason for this separation?
options: The LORD's hand is shortened and cannot save
Their iniquities have separated them from God
God is unwilling to hear prayers
They lack enough faith to be heard
questions.correctAnswer: Their iniquities have separated them from God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:2 clearly states that our sins separate us from God and hide His face from us, causing Him not to hear. This shows that sin is the barrier, not a lack of power or willingness on God's part (Isaiah 59:1, 59:2, 59:13).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 59 teach us about the importance of honesty and integrity in daily life?
options: Lying and perverseness defile our hands and tongues
Falsehoods are acceptable if no one is harmed
Justice and truth are less important than success
Deceit can be used to protect oneself
questions.correctAnswer: Lying and perverseness defile our hands and tongues
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:3-4 highlights that lying lips and a muttering tongue are signs of iniquity, which separate us from God. Honesty and truth are vital because justice and truth have been abandoned (Isaiah 59:3, 59:4, 59:14).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to find peace in a chaotic world. Based on Isaiah 59, what biblical truth would you share about the way of peace?
options: The way of peace is unknown to those who pursue evil
Peace can be found by wealth and power
questions.correctAnswer: The way of peace is unknown to those who pursue evil
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:8 explains that those who choose crooked paths and do not know judgment or peace will not find it. The way of peace comes by turning from evil and pursuing justice (Isaiah 59:7-9, 59:14).

questions.question: What does Isaiah 59 teach about God’s response when there is no intercessor or one to stand in the gap for others?
options: God’s arm brings salvation and sustains with righteousness
God punishes the people without mercy
God leaves them to their own devices
questions.correctAnswer: God’s arm brings salvation and sustains with righteousness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:16 shows that when God saw no intercessor, His arm brought salvation and His righteousness sustained Him, teaching us about God’s active intervention and the importance of intercession (Isaiah 59:15-17).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59, how should believers respond to enemies and opposition?
options: Trust God’s justice and His zeal as a cloak
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God’s justice and His zeal as a cloak
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:17 describes God putting on righteousness as a breastplate and zeal as a cloak, symbolizing that God will execute judgment and believers should trust His righteous defense rather than personal vengeance (Isaiah 59:17-19).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to despair because justice seems absent. What encouragement does Isaiah 59 provide about God's justice?
options: Justice is far away and will never come
God will repay according to deeds and raise a standard against enemies
We should take justice into our own hands
Justice is irrelevant in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: God will repay according to deeds and raise a standard against enemies
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:18-19 assures that God will repay adversaries according to their deeds and that His Spirit will rise to protect His people, teaching believers to trust God's timing and justice (Isaiah 59:14, 59:18-19).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 59 illustrate the consequence of trusting in vanity and speaking lies in our relationships and community?
options: It leads to fruitful and peaceful outcomes
It causes mischief and iniquity to increase
questions.correctAnswer: It causes mischief and iniquity to increase
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:4 explains that trusting in vanity and speaking lies leads to conceiving mischief and producing iniquity, which damages relationships and community life (Isaiah 59:3-5).

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 59, God’s power to save is limited and His ear is heavy, so He cannot always hear our prayers.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:1 states that the LORD’s hand is not shortened so He cannot save, nor is His ear heavy so He cannot hear, indicating God’s power and attentiveness are unlimited; the barrier is human sin (Isaiah 59:1-2).

questions.question: What practical lesson about humility and repentance can we learn from Isaiah 59:12-13?
options: Ignoring our sins is the best way to move forward
Confessing and recognizing transgressions is necessary before God
Justifying our sins protects us from judgment
Sins have no real effect on our relationship with God
questions.correctAnswer: Confessing and recognizing transgressions is necessary before God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:12-13 emphasizes that transgressions multiply and testify against us, and recognizing them is critical for reconciliation, teaching humility and repentance as essential spiritual disciplines (Isaiah 59:2, 59:12-13).

questions.question: A church community is struggling with a lack of justice and truth. According to Isaiah 59, what biblical truth would you share about the state of truth and equity?
options: Truth and equity have fallen and cannot enter
Truth and equity are irrelevant in difficult times
Justice will come only through human effort
questions.correctAnswer: Truth and equity have fallen and cannot enter
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:14 states that truth has fallen in the street and equity cannot enter, highlighting the need for spiritual renewal and reliance on God’s justice rather than human strength alone (Isaiah 59:14-15).

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 59 teaches that those who depart from evil make themselves vulnerable and become prey.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:15 mentions that those who depart from evil make themselves a prey, indicating the dangers of righteousness in a corrupt world, but God sees this and it displeases Him, emphasizing the need for divine justice (Isaiah 59:15-16).

questions.question: How does Isaiah 59 encourage believers to persevere through trials and darkness?
options: By groping blindly for answers alone
By recognizing their sins and waiting on the LORD’s salvation
By ignoring the darkness and focusing on self
questions.correctAnswer: By recognizing their sins and waiting on the LORD’s salvation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:9-11 describes walking in darkness and groaning like bears while waiting for light and salvation, teaching perseverance through repentance and hopeful expectation in God’s deliverance (Isaiah 59:2, 59:9-11).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 59:21 promises that God's covenant includes His spirit and words that will not depart out of the mouth of the believer, nor out of the mouth of their ____, nor out of the mouth of their seed's seed.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:21 promises a lasting covenant where God's spirit and words remain with the believer and their descendants, emphasizing faithfulness across generations.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59, what role does God’s Spirit play when enemies come like a flood?
options: The Spirit flees to protect itself
The Spirit lifts up a standard against the enemy
The Spirit allows the enemy to prevail
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit lifts up a standard against the enemy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:19 teaches that when enemies come in like a flood, the Spirit of the LORD will lift up a standard against them, providing protection and encouragement for believers to trust God in adversity (Isaiah 59:19-20).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because they see no justice in their situation. How does Isaiah 59 explain God’s judgment and recompense?
options: God repays according to deeds with fury to adversaries
Justice is delayed and never fulfilled
questions.correctAnswer: God repays according to deeds with fury to adversaries
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:18 describes God repaying according to deeds, bringing fury to adversaries and recompense to enemies, encouraging believers to trust God’s righteous judgment rather than despair (Isaiah 59:14, 59:18).

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 59 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 59.

questions.question: What is the primary reason given in Isaiah 59 for the separation between God and the people?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:2 states that their iniquities have separated between them and their God, causing God to hide His face.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Isaiah 59, their lips have spoken ____, and their tongue hath muttered perverseness.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:3 clearly states that their lips have spoken lies, indicating deceitful speech.

questions.question: Isaiah 59 uses which imagery to describe the evil works and consequences of the people?
questions.explanation: Verse 5 uses the metaphor of hatching cockatrice' eggs and weaving spider’s webs to illustrate the harmful nature of their deeds.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 59 says that their works will become garments that cover them.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:6 states that their webs shall not become garments, meaning their evil deeds will not protect or cover them.

questions.question: What are the thoughts of the people described as in Isaiah 59:7?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:7 explicitly says their thoughts are thoughts of iniquity, reflecting a mindset of wickedness.

questions.question: Isaiah 59:8 uses which literary device to describe the people's paths?
questions.explanation: Verse 8 metaphorically describes the people's ways as crooked paths where no peace is found, illustrating their moral deviation.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 59:10 describe the people's condition in darkness?
options: They grope for the wall like the blind
questions.correctAnswer: They grope for the wall like the blind
questions.explanation: Verse 10 uses the simile of groping for the wall like the blind to illustrate the people's confusion and helplessness.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase "we roar all like bears" in Isaiah 59:11?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:11 uses roaring like bears and mourning like doves to depict the people's lamentation and distress over the lack of justice.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59:13, what kind of words do the people conceive and utter from their hearts?
questions.explanation: Verse 13 indicates that the people conceive and utter words of falsehood from their hearts, showing deep-seated deceit.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 59:14 say has fallen in the street, indicating societal collapse?
questions.explanation: The verse states that truth has fallen in the street, symbolizing public breakdown of integrity and justice.

questions.question: In Isaiah 59:16, what does God do because He saw there was no intercessor?
options: His arm brought salvation and sustained him with righteousness
He sends an angel to punish
questions.correctAnswer: His arm brought salvation and sustained him with righteousness
questions.explanation: Verse 16 reveals God's active intervention, bringing salvation by His own arm and being sustained by His righteousness due to the lack of intercessors.

questions.question: How is God's armor described in Isaiah 59:17?
options: Breastplate of righteousness and helmet of salvation
Shield of faith and sword of truth
Armor of light and helmet of holiness
Breastplate of justice and helmet of mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Breastplate of righteousness and helmet of salvation
questions.explanation: Verse 17 depicts God putting on righteousness as a breastplate and salvation as a helmet, symbolizing divine protection and judgment.

questions.question: Isaiah 59:19 contains a promise that when the enemy comes like a flood, what will the Spirit of the LORD do?
options: Lift up a standard against him
questions.correctAnswer: Lift up a standard against him
questions.explanation: The verse promises that the Spirit of the LORD will raise a standard, a banner of defense, against overwhelming enemies.

questions.question: Who is described as coming to Zion in Isaiah 59:20?
questions.explanation: Verse 20 prophesies the coming of the Redeemer to Zion, indicating a future deliverance for those turning from sin.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 59:21 promises that God's covenant and spirit will depart from the mouth of the prophet and his descendants.
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:21 asserts that God's spirit and words will not depart from the mouth of the prophet nor his descendants forever, showing covenantal faithfulness.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 59 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 59 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59:1, what is true about the LORD's ability to save and hear?
options: The LORD's hand is not shortened to save, nor His ear heavy to hear
The LORD is unable to hear the cries of His people
The LORD’s power to save is limited by human sin
The LORD does not hear the prayers of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD's hand is not shortened to save, nor His ear heavy to hear
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:1 emphasizes God's unlimited power and attentiveness: 'Behold, the LORD'S hand is not shortened, that it cannot save; neither his ear heavy, that it cannot hear.' This affirms God's omnipotence and omnipresence. Similarly, Psalm 34:15 and 1 John 5:14 affirm God's readiness to hear and save His people.

questions.question: What reason does Isaiah 59:2 give for God not hearing His people?
options: Their iniquities have separated them from God
God punishes them by ignoring their cries
questions.correctAnswer: Their iniquities have separated them from God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:2 states, 'But your iniquities have separated between you and your God, and your sins have hid his face from you, that he will not hear.' Sin causes alienation from God, consistent with Romans 3:23 and Isaiah 59:1-2, showing the barrier sin creates. This theme is echoed in Psalm 66:18 and Ezekiel 14:4.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Isaiah 59:3, 'For your hands are defiled with _______, and your fingers with iniquity.'
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:3 explicitly says, 'For your hands are defiled with blood, and your fingers with iniquity.' This highlights the guilt of violence and sin, reflecting the biblical principle that sin pollutes the human condition (Genesis 4:10; Proverbs 6:16-17; Matthew 23:35).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59:4, what do the people fail to call for or plead?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:4 states, 'None calleth for justice, nor any pleadeth for truth.' This indicates societal moral decay, where justice and truth are abandoned. This failure contrasts with Micah 6:8 and Amos 5:24’s calls for justice and righteousness.

questions.question: What imagery does Isaiah 59:5 use to describe the consequences of their evil deeds?
options: Hatching cockatrice' eggs and weaving spider’s webs
Carrying heavy burdens on their backs
questions.correctAnswer: Hatching cockatrice' eggs and weaving spider’s webs
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:5 uses the metaphor of 'They hatch cockatrice' eggs, and weave the spider's web' to symbolize dangerous and fragile evil plans that bring death and harm. This imagery aligns with Proverbs 30:28 and Job 8:14 about destructive deceit.

questions.question: Isaiah 59:6 states that their works cannot become garments or cover themselves because their works are what?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:6 says, 'Their works are works of iniquity, and the act of violence is in their hands.' This underlines that sinful deeds cannot provide true protection or justification, matching themes in Romans 3:20 and Galatians 2:16 about works and righteousness.

questions.question: What do the feet of the wicked do according to Isaiah 59:7?
options: Run to evil and make haste to shed innocent blood
Walk in the way of righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Run to evil and make haste to shed innocent blood
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:7 states, 'Their feet run to evil, and they make haste to shed innocent blood,' highlighting active pursuit of sin and violence. This corresponds with Proverbs 1:16 and Romans 1:29 about the eagerness to do evil.

questions.question: Isaiah 59:8 says that the wicked have made their paths what, and what is the result for those who walk in them?
options: Crooked paths; they shall not know peace
Straight paths; they shall find rest
Narrow paths; they shall be saved
Wide paths; they shall be destroyed
questions.correctAnswer: Crooked paths; they shall not know peace
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:8 states, 'they have made them crooked paths: whosoever goeth therein shall not know peace.' This implies moral and spiritual distortion leads to unrest, consistent with Proverbs 3:17 and Romans 3:17.

questions.question: What is described in Isaiah 59:9 as being far from the people, causing them to walk in darkness?
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:9 says, 'Therefore is judgment far from us, neither doth justice overtake us... we walk in darkness.' The absence of judgment and justice leads to spiritual blindness and despair, paralleling Isaiah 5:20 and John 3:19.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59:10, how do the people move without judgment and justice?
options: They grope like the blind and stumble at noonday
They walk confidently in the light
They stand firmly on the rock of God
questions.correctAnswer: They grope like the blind and stumble at noonday
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:10 describes, 'We grope for the wall like the blind... we stumble at noonday as in the night,' symbolizing confusion and helplessness without God's guidance. This is consistent with 1 Corinthians 13:12 and Psalm 18:28.

questions.question: Isaiah 59:12 states that our transgressions have multiplied before God and testify against us. What theological truth does this emphasize?
options: Sin has a personal and accusatory effect before God
God ignores the sins of His people
Only external actions matter to God
Sin can be hidden from God
questions.correctAnswer: Sin has a personal and accusatory effect before God
questions.explanation: The verse highlights that sin is not just a private matter but testifies against us before God, affirming God's holiness and justice (Psalm 51:4; Romans 3:19; Hebrews 4:13).

questions.question: In Isaiah 59:14, what has fallen in the street, and what cannot enter?
options: Truth has fallen; equity cannot enter
Peace has fallen; joy cannot enter
Grace has fallen; mercy cannot enter
Faith has fallen; hope cannot enter
questions.correctAnswer: Truth has fallen; equity cannot enter
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:14 states, 'for truth is fallen in the street, and equity cannot enter,' indicating societal collapse of justice and honesty, paralleling Proverbs 14:34 and Romans 1:18-25.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 59:16 reveal about God’s response when there was no intercessor?
options: His arm brought salvation and His righteousness sustained Him
questions.correctAnswer: His arm brought salvation and His righteousness sustained Him
questions.explanation: Verse 16 says, 'therefore his arm brought salvation unto him; and his righteousness, it sustained him,' demonstrating God's active intervention to save, prefiguring Christ’s intercession (Romans 8:34; Hebrews 7:25).

questions.question: According to Isaiah 59:17, what metaphorical armor does the LORD put on?
options: Righteousness as breastplate and helmet of salvation
Breastplate of faith and shield of hope
Sword of the Spirit and belt of truth
Garments of humility and sandals of peace
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness as breastplate and helmet of salvation
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:17 describes God putting on 'righteousness as a breastplate, and an helmet of salvation,' symbolizing divine protection and justice, echoed in Ephesians 6:14-17.

questions.question: In Isaiah 59:19, what will the Spirit of the LORD do when the enemy comes 'like a flood'?
options: Lift up a standard against him
questions.correctAnswer: Lift up a standard against him
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:19 proclaims, 'When the enemy shall come in like a flood, the Spirit of the LORD shall lift up a standard against him,' showing God's protective power through the Spirit, consistent with Ezekiel 36:27 and Acts 1:8.
